facts.text: Village Bilati Khet cursed with keen rivalry and enmity between two factions: one led by Gayadin, the other by Laxmi Prasad alias Laxmi Narain.
In last village Panchayat election, Laxmi Prasad succeeded as Pradhan defeating Gayadin's candidate.
On 28th November 1961, boundary dispute between fields of Gayadin and Laxmi Prasad; arbitration attempts failed; Laxmi Prasad's group threatened to settle matter next day.
On 29th November 1961 early morning, Bahoran (son of Gayadin) met Laxmi Prasad in field; Laxmi attacked with lathi; Bahoran retaliated with pharsa, injuring Laxmi's nose.
Infuriated Laxmi Prasad collected crowd from his faction, armed with guns, spears, swords, gandasas, lathis, proceeding to Gayadin's house.
Ram Prasad and Dayaram informed Gayadin's group of approaching armed crowd.
Assailants reached Gayadin's house around 8 a.m.; Laxmi Prasad fired gun; Bhagwati instigated to exterminate Gayadin's family.
Victims rushed inside and closed doors; assailants broke open doors, entered sehan, pursued and killed Gayadin on upper storey.
Brindaban, Radha Saran, and Dayaram hiding in rooms; doors broken, shot dead.
Bahoran and Shiroman Singh (sons of Gayadin) escaped via roof to Harbans' cattleshed; Shiroman hid in godown, Bahoran in chaff room.
Assailants dragged bodies out; Gori Dulaiya (Gayadin's wife) implored, struck with stick.
Assailants entered Harbans' cattleshed, injured Harbans, killed Shiroman Singh.
Five bodies (Gayadin, Brindaban, Radha Saran, Dayaram, Shiroman Singh) taken to Bhagwati's field; placed on dung cake piles, kerosene sprinkled, set on fire.
Bahoran lodged FIR at 11 a.m. naming 35 assailants; later 5 more added.
Police extinguished fire, recovered half-burnt bodies, sent for post-mortem; injured (Harbans, Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram, Gori Dulaiya) for medical exam.
40 accused charged; trial by First Additional Sessions Judge, Jhansi.
Trial Judge convicted 35/40 under s.302/149 IPC etc.; 10 death, 25 life; acquitted 5.
35 convicted appealed to Allahabad HC; death references for 10.
HC acquitted 7/35; confirmed 28 convictions/sentences; confirmed 10 death sentences.
16 accused appealed to SC by special leave.
Prosecution case by 12 eye-witnesses; defence denied involvement, alleged false case by hostile witnesses.
HC discarded evidence of Bahoran (PW1) and Prabhu Dayal (PW5) due to infirmities; accepted 10 others despite partisanship; convicted if 4+ witnesses consistent.
Prosecution did not examine Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram (won over), Rani Dulhan (mental shock); trial court rejected defence applications under s.540 CrPC.
Accused Nos. 9 Ram Saran (18 yrs), 11 Asha Ram (23 yrs, son of Bhagwati), 16 Deo Prasad (24 yrs) young and likely joined under elder pressure.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court properly discharged duty under s.374 CrPC in confirming death sentences, considering entire evidence independently.
Whether evidence of partisan witnesses can be discarded solely on ground of partisanship.
Whether uniform pattern of evidence without specific overt acts proves membership in unlawful assembly under ss.141,142,149 IPC.
Whether failure to examine certain prosecution witnesses vitiates trial.
Whether death sentence under s.302/149 IPC can be imposed without proof of individual overt act of murder.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court failed to independently consider entire evidence as required by s.374 CrPC for death confirmation; relied on Jumman v. State of Punjab.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.374, 375 CrPC; Jumman Ors. v. State of Punjab AIR 1957 SC 469

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution suppressed material witnesses (Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram, Rani Dulhan); trial court erred in not summoning under s.540 CrPC.
Partisan witnesses from victims' faction; evidence should be discarded due to enmity.
Evidence uniform, no specific overt acts assigned except to Laxmi Prasad; mere presence does not prove unlawful assembly membership.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Baladin v. State of U.P. AIR 1956 SC 181; ss.141,142,149 IPC

petitioner_arguments.text: HC's 4-witness test mechanical; single trustworthy witness sufficient.
Death sentence mechanical for gun-carriers; only if individual committed murder; Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 1954 SCR 145; s.302/149 IPC

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution witnesses won over or unable to depose coherently; not essential; defence could examine.

court_reasoning.text: HC carefully examined evidence, arguments, infirmities; applied safe test of 4 consistent witnesses despite partisanship; criticism not well-founded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: HC judgment shows due care; rejected Bahoran and Prabhu Dayal evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Partisan evidence not to be mechanically rejected; must weigh discrepancies, genuineness, probability; common in faction cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejection solely on partisanship leads to failure of justice.

court_reasoning.text: Uniform evidence expected in unlawful assembly attacks; not all need participate in assault; weapons carried in pursuance of common object.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.149 vicarious liability; no need for individual overt acts for membership.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecutor not bound to tender won-over/terrorised witnesses; defence/applications under s.540 rejected after consideration; not essential.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial court finding of fact unchallenged.

court_reasoning.text: 4-witness test useful in multi-accused cases though quality matters; mechanical but not irrational.
Baladin observation contextual; membership if aware and intentionally joined/entertained common object under s.141/142; all from Laxmi faction armed for extermination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No unqualified rule requiring overt act.

court_reasoning.text: Death sentence justified for 10 gun-armed in gruesome faction murders to suppress; not mechanical; discretion proper.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts warrant extreme penalty despite s.149.

court_reasoning.text: Reduce death to life for young accused 9,11,16 (18,23,24 yrs) likely compelled by elders.

holdings.text: High Court properly considered evidence under s.374 CrPC; convictions under s.302/149 IPC confirmed.
Partisan evidence assessible if reliable; not discarded mechanically.
Unlawful assembly membership proved without individual overt acts if common object shared.
No infirmity in not examining certain witnesses.
Death sentence permissible under s.302/149 without personal killing if circumstances extreme; confirmed except for 3 young accused.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jumman Ors. v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court must independently consider entire evidence in death sentence confirmation under s.374 CrPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Mere presence not membership; but contextual to passive witnesses; here all shared common object.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate enhancement to death rare; inapplicable as no enhancement here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Principal charges; unlawful assembly with common object to murder; vicarious liability.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Death confirmation requires independent HC review; power to call witnesses.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals against convictions of 16 appellants under s.302/149 IPC and others; confirmed death sentences on 7 of 10; reduced death to life imprisonment for accused Nos. 9 (Ram Saran, 18), 11 (Asha Ram, 23), 16 (Deo Prasad, 24) considering youth and family pressure.
outcome.relief_granted: Sentences modified to life imprisonment for three young appellants.

key_quotes.text: "the sentence of death shall not be executed unless it is confirmed by the High Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasises solemnity and independent review under s.374 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: "evidence given by witnesses should be discarded only on the ground that it is evidence of partisan or interested witnesses."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects mechanical rejection of factional evidence.

key_quotes.text: "unless an overt act is proved against a person who is alleged to be a member of an unlawful assembly, it cannot be said that he is a member."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes Baladin; clarifies no general rule for overt acts.

key_quotes.text: "the whole group of persons who constituted the assembly were members of the faction of Laxmi Prasad and they assembled together, armed with several weapons."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for upholding unlawful assembly finding.
